clinical_study.brief_title: Effects of a 12-week Strength Training Program in Men With Myotonic Dystrophy Type 1
clinical_study.official_title: Effects of a 12-week Strength Training Program in Men With Myotonic Dystrophy Type 1

collaborator.agency: Fondation du Grand défi Pierre Lavoie

brief_summary.textblock: Eleven men with myotonic dystrophy type 1 (DM1) underwent a 12-week lower-limb strength training program. The training program consisted of 3 series of 6 to 8 maximal repetitions of 5 different exercises: Leg extension, leg press, hip abduction, squat and plantar flexion. Training sessions were closely supervised and took place twice a week. It is hypothesised that the training program will induce muscular hypertrophy despite the genetic defect. The training program should also have positive effects on function. The participants were evaluated at baseline, week 6, week 12, month 6 and month 9 to see the effects of the training program and if these effects are maintained over time.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Participants had to complete a 12-week strength training program and return to their normal activities for the following 6 months after the end of the training program
study_design_info.masking_description: Most outcomes where not masked, however the outcome assessor was masked for all muscle biopsy analysis: while analysing the muscle biopsy outcomes, the outcome assessor did not know if it was from baseline or from after the training program.

primary_outcome.measure: Changes in maximal isometric muscle strength of the knee extensors
primary_outcome.time_frame: At baseline, week 6, week 12, month 6 and month 9
primary_outcome.description: Changes in maximal isometric muscle strength of the knee extensors measured by quantified muscle testing using a handheld dynamometer

secondary_outcome.measure: Changes in maximal isometric muscle strength of the knee flexors
secondary_outcome.description: Changes in maximal isometric muscle strength of the knee flexors measured by quantified muscle testing using a handheld dynamometer

secondary_outcome.measure: Changes in comfortable walking speed in the 10-meter walk test
secondary_outcome.time_frame: At baseline, week 6, week 12, month 6 and month 9
secondary_outcome.description: Changes in comfortable walking speed in the 10-meter walk test

secondary_outcome.measure: Changes in maximal walking speed in the 10-meter walk test
secondary_outcome.time_frame: At baseline, week 6, week 12, month 6 and month 9
secondary_outcome.description: Changes in maximal walking speed in the 10-meter walk test

secondary_outcome.measure: Changes in the number of repetitions in the 30-seconds sit-to-stand test
secondary_outcome.time_frame: At baseline, week 6, week 12, month 6 and month 9
secondary_outcome.description: Changes in the number of repetitions in the 30-seconds sit-to-stand test

secondary_outcome.measure: Changes in the score of the lower extremity functional scale
secondary_outcome.time_frame: At baseline, week 12, month 6 and month 9
secondary_outcome.description: Changes in the score of the lower extremity functional scale (LEFS). The LEFS is an 80-point questionnaire with 20 items scored from 0 to 4. A score of 80 means no disfunction while a score of 0 means maximal disfunction.

secondary_outcome.measure: Changes in the score of the myotonic dystrophy health index
secondary_outcome.time_frame: At baseline, week 6, week 12, month 6 and month 9
secondary_outcome.description: Changes in the score of the myotonic dystrophy health index (MDHI). The MDHI is a 114-item questionnaire scored from 0 to 100, where 0 means no disability and 100 means maximal disability.

secondary_outcome.measure: Changes in the score of the Fatigue and Daytime Sleepiness Scale
secondary_outcome.time_frame: At baseline, week 6, week 12, month 6 and month 9
secondary_outcome.description: Changes in the score of the Fatigue and Daytime Sleepiness Scale (FDSS). The FDSS is a 12-item questionnaire where all questions are scored from 0 to 2. A higher score means more daytime sleepiness and fatigue.

secondary_outcome.measure: Changes in the Marin apathy scale
secondary_outcome.time_frame: At baseline, week 12, month 6 and month 9
secondary_outcome.description: Changes in the Marin apathy scale. The Marin apathy scale is scored by the clinician where he interviews the subject and then scores an 18-item list on a scale of 1 to 4. A high score means more apathy.

secondary_outcome.measure: Changes in the Well-Being Manifestations Measure Scale
secondary_outcome.time_frame: At baseline, week 6, week 12 and month 6
secondary_outcome.description: Changes in the Well-Being Manifestations Measure Scale (WBMMS). The WBMMS is a 25-item questionnaire where each question is scored on a scale from 1 to 5. A high score means high well-being.

secondary_outcome.measure: Changes in the Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale
secondary_outcome.time_frame: At baseline, week 6, week 12 and month 6
secondary_outcome.description: Changes in the Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS). The HADS is a 14-item questionnaire with a scale from 0 to 3 for each item. A high score means high depression and anxiety.

secondary_outcome.measure: Changes in muscle biopsy of the vastus lateralis: muscle fiber typing
secondary_outcome.description: Changes in muscle biopsy of the vastus lateralis: muscle fiber typing

secondary_outcome.measure: Changes in muscle biopsy of the vastus lateralis: muscle fiber size
secondary_outcome.description: Changes in muscle biopsy of the vastus lateralis: muscle fiber size (smallest diameter of the fiber)

secondary_outcome.measure: Changes in muscle biopsy of the vastus lateralis: muscle proteomics
secondary_outcome.description: Changes in muscle biopsy of the vastus lateralis: muscle proteomics (protein expression)

intervention.description: 12-week strength training program of the lower limbs consisting of 5 different exercises: Leg extension, leg press, hip abduction, squat and plantar flexion. All exercises were performed between 6 and 8 maximal repetitions.
